title: How to Season Roast Beef

steps.headline: Blend the salt, pepper, and garlic powder while the oven preheats.
steps.description:
Set the oven to 375 °F (191 °C). While it’s preheating, use a fork to stir the following spices together in a small bowl:
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) kosher salt
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) garlic powder
0.25 tsp (1.25 g) black pepper
If you like your roast more heavily seasoned, you can increase each of these amounts by 0.25 tsp (2.5 g).

steps.headline: Sprinkle the seasoning over the whole roast and pat it in.
steps.description: Use your thumb and fingertips to sprinkle the seasoning blend evenly over all sides of the roast. Lightly pat the roast with your hand to help adhere the seasoning to it. Don’t try to save time by just seasoning the top of the roast. Adding seasoning to all sides will give the roast a more consistent flavor.

steps.headline: Tie up the roast with cooking twine, if necessary.
steps.description: Many butcher shops will tie up a roast for you upon request. If you’re tying it yourself, double-knot lengths of cooking twine around the roast at 3 in (7.6 cm) intervals. The goal of tying is to give the roast a consistent shape and thickness. Aim to give the roast a roughly cylindrical shape when you tie it up. But don’t worry if it isn’t perfect! Use cotton twine specifically intended for cooking.

steps.headline: Place the beef in a roasting pan and cook it for 60 minutes.
steps.description: For many cooks, the rule of thumb for roast beef is to cook it for 20 minutes per 1 lb (0.45 kg). Since this is a 3 lb (1.4 kg) roast, plan for an hour of cooking time. If you choose to check the temperature with a probe thermometer while cooking, remove the roast from the oven when the internal temperature reaches 140 °F (60 °C). The temperature will increase to the recommended 145 °F (63 °C) internal temperature while the roast rests.

steps.headline: Cover the roast and let it rest for 15-20 minutes.
steps.description: With the roast still in the pan, loosely cover it with one or more sheets of aluminum foil. During this 15-20 minute resting period, the internal temperature will rise to 145 °F (63 °C) and the meat’s juices will redistribute more evenly. If you cut into the roast right away, more of the juices will run out, leaving the meat with a dry texture. It also may not have reached the recommended internal temperature.

steps.headline: Carve and serve the roast beef.
steps.description: This size of roast will typically serve 6 people. Consider pairing it with mashed potatoes and gravy for a classic combination, or try white rice and roasted vegetables. Refrigerate any leftovers immediately and use them within 3 days.

methods.name: Dried Herbs and Spices Seasoning Blend

steps.headline: Whisk the ingredients together in a medium bowl.
steps.description:
Measure and add the flour, dried herbs, and spices to the bowl. Use a whisk to combine them thoroughly. The ingredients include:
1 c (225 g) flour
2 tsp (10 g) dried oregano
1 tbsp (15 g) dried basil
1 tsp (5 g) dried rosemary
1 tbsp (15 g) dried parsley
1 tbsp (15 g) salt
2 tbsp (30 g) black pepper
2 tbsp (30 g) paprika
1 tbsp (15 g) celery seed

steps.headline: Add the ingredients to a 2  c (470 mL) jar.
steps.description: A glass canning jar with a screw-top lid makes a good choice. Either spoon the mixture into the jar, or use a kitchen funnel and pour the contents of the bowl into the jar. If you can find a large enough spice jar with a shaker cap that clips on under the screw-top lid, you’ll be able to easily shake your seasoning mix onto your favorite foods.

steps.headline: Sprinkle and pat the seasoning on beef before roasting.
Store the mixture in a cool, dry cabinet for up to 1 year.
steps.description: Label the jar and add a “use by” date to it. After about a year of storage, the flour may start to develop an unpleasant texture, odor, and/or flavor. Dried herbs also begin to lose their flavor after about 1 year. If you store the blend in the refrigerator, it will keep for up to 2 years. Keep the jar out of sunlight while storing it. Use a closed cabinet or pantry cupboard instead of an open spice rack.

steps.headline: Season potatoes, veggies, sauces, soups, and more with this blend.
steps.description: This is a very versatile seasoning blend that infuses practically any dish with an aroma that you’ll naturally associate with roast beef. Also, since it contains flour, it can be used as a seasoned thickening agent in sauces or soups. Add this blend to roasted potatoes or vegetables to give them a “beefy” aroma while keeping them vegetarian-friendly.

methods.name: Other Seasoning Options with Beer Marinade

steps.headline: Try spiking the roast with slivers of garlic.
steps.description: Cut 3-4 cloves of garlic into halves or thirds so you have 8-10 slivers. Use the tip of a sharp knife to make 8-10 slits in the uncooked roast beef. Insert a garlic sliver into each of the slits. Then, season all sides of the roast with salt, pepper, and/or your preferred seasoning blend, and cook it as directed by your recipe. To help your seasonings adhere better, consider brushing the entire roast with 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of olive oil first.

steps.headline: Marinate the roast in beer and seasonings for a tender, savory dish.
steps.description: Add 12  fl oz (350 mL) of dark beer, 1 chopped medium onion, 8 minced garlic cloves, 1 thinly sliced lemon, 1  c (240 mL) soy sauce, and 2 US tbsp (30 mL) vegetable oil to a large zip-close freezer bag. Place the uncooked roast into the bag and seal it. Massage the marinade into the meat with your hands, then refrigerate it for at least 8 hours, but ideally for 24 hours. Because the soy sauce is salty, don’t add any extra salt to the outside of the roast before cooking. Instead, consider adding nothing but 1 tsp (5 g) of black pepper.

steps.headline: Try coating the roast in mustard paste.
steps.description: Mix 1 tbsp (15 g) of mustard powder with just enough water to create a thick paste. Rub this mustard paste in an even layer over the entire roast. Season the outside of the roast with 0.5 tsp (2.5 g) of salt and 0.25 tsp (1.25 g) of black pepper, then cook the roast as directed by your recipe. As a variation, sear the outside of the roast after adding the mustard paste but before applying the salt and pepper. Heat 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat, then add the roast to the pan. Use tongs to turn the roast so that each side gets nicely browned. Remove the roast, let it cool for a couple minutes, then apply the salt and pepper and finish cooking it in the oven.

text:
Simply Seasoned Roast Beef Blend the salt, pepper, and garlic powder while the oven preheats. Set the oven to 375 °F (191 °C). While it’s preheating, use a fork to stir the following spices together in a small bowl:
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) kosher salt
0.5 tsp (2.5 g) garlic powder
0.25 tsp (1.25 g) black pepper
If you like your roast more heavily seasoned, you can increase each of these amounts by 0.25 tsp (2.5 g). Sprinkle the seasoning over the whole roast and pat it in. Use your thumb and fingertips to sprinkle the seasoning blend evenly over all sides of the roast. Lightly pat the roast with your hand to help adhere the seasoning to it. Don’t try to save time by just seasoning the top of the roast. Adding seasoning to all sides will give the roast a more consistent flavor. Tie up the roast with cooking twine, if necessary. Many butcher shops will tie up a roast for you upon request. If you’re tying it yourself, double-knot lengths of cooking twine around the roast at 3 in (7.6 cm) intervals. The goal of tying is to give the roast a consistent shape and thickness. Aim to give the roast a roughly cylindrical shape when you tie it up. But don’t worry if it isn’t perfect! Use cotton twine specifically intended for cooking. Place the beef in a roasting pan and cook it for 60 minutes. For many cooks, the rule of thumb for roast beef is to cook it for 20 minutes per 1 lb (0.45 kg). Since this is a 3 lb (1.4 kg) roast, plan for an hour of cooking time. If you choose to check the temperature with a probe thermometer while cooking, remove the roast from the oven when the internal temperature reaches 140 °F (60 °C). The temperature will increase to the recommended 145 °F (63 °C) internal temperature while the roast rests. Cover the roast and let it rest for 15-20 minutes. With the roast still in the pan, loosely cover it with one or more sheets of aluminum foil. During this 15-20 minute resting period, the internal temperature will rise to 145 °F (63 °C) and the meat’s juices will redistribute more evenly. If you cut into the roast right away, more of the juices will run out, leaving the meat with a dry texture. It also may not have reached the recommended internal temperature. Carve and serve the roast beef. This size of roast will typically serve 6 people. Consider pairing it with mashed potatoes and gravy for a classic combination, or try white rice and roasted vegetables. Refrigerate any leftovers immediately and use them within 3 days. Dried Herbs and Spices Seasoning Blend Whisk the ingredients together in a medium bowl. Measure and add the flour, dried herbs, and spices to the bowl. Use a whisk to combine them thoroughly. The ingredients include:
1 c (225 g) flour
2 tsp (10 g) dried oregano
1 tbsp (15 g) dried basil
1 tsp (5 g) dried rosemary
1 tbsp (15 g) dried parsley
1 tbsp (15 g) salt
2 tbsp (30 g) black pepper
2 tbsp (30 g) paprika
1 tbsp (15 g) celery seed Add the ingredients to a 2  c (470 mL) jar. A glass canning jar with a screw-top lid makes a good choice. Either spoon the mixture into the jar, or use a kitchen funnel and pour the contents of the bowl into the jar. If you can find a large enough spice jar with a shaker cap that clips on under the screw-top lid, you’ll be able to easily shake your seasoning mix onto your favorite foods. Sprinkle and pat the seasoning on beef before roasting. For a 3 lb (1.4 kg) roast, sprinkle about 1.5 tsp (7.5 g) of this blend evenly on all sides and massage it in gently with your fingers. Then, continue with your recipe as instructed. For instance, your recipe may advise you to:
season the beef;
tie it with cooking twine at 3 in (7.6 cm) intervals to give it a cylindrical shape;
use a roasting pan to cook it in a 375 °F (191 °C) oven;
remove it when the beef's internal temperature reads 140 °F (60 °C);
cover the roast with foil and let it rest for 10 minutes before serving. Store the mixture in a cool, dry cabinet for up to 1 year. Label the jar and add a “use by” date to it. After about a year of storage, the flour may start to develop an unpleasant texture, odor, and/or flavor. Dried herbs also begin to lose their flavor after about 1 year. If you store the blend in the refrigerator, it will keep for up to 2 years. Keep the jar out of sunlight while storing it. Use a closed cabinet or pantry cupboard instead of an open spice rack. Season potatoes, veggies, sauces, soups, and more with this blend. This is a very versatile seasoning blend that infuses practically any dish with an aroma that you’ll naturally associate with roast beef. Also, since it contains flour, it can be used as a seasoned thickening agent in sauces or soups. Add this blend to roasted potatoes or vegetables to give them a “beefy” aroma while keeping them vegetarian-friendly. Other Seasoning Options with Beer Marinade Try spiking the roast with slivers of garlic. Cut 3-4 cloves of garlic into halves or thirds so you have 8-10 slivers. Use the tip of a sharp knife to make 8-10 slits in the uncooked roast beef. Insert a garlic sliver into each of the slits. Then, season all sides of the roast with salt, pepper, and/or your preferred seasoning blend, and cook it as directed by your recipe. To help your seasonings adhere better, consider brushing the entire roast with 1 US tbsp (15 mL) of olive oil first. Marinate the roast in beer and seasonings for a tender, savory dish. Add 12  fl oz (350 mL) of dark beer, 1 chopped medium onion, 8 minced garlic cloves, 1 thinly sliced lemon, 1  c (240 mL) soy sauce, and 2 US tbsp (30 mL) vegetable oil to a large zip-close freezer bag. Place the uncooked roast into the bag and seal it. Massage the marinade into the meat with your hands, then refrigerate it for at least 8 hours, but ideally for 24 hours. Because the soy sauce is salty, don’t add any extra salt to the outside of the roast before cooking. Instead, consider adding nothing but 1 tsp (5 g) of black pepper. Try coating the roast in mustard paste. Mix 1 tbsp (15 g) of mustard powder with just enough water to create a thick paste. Rub this mustard paste in an even layer over the entire roast. Season the outside of the roast with 0.5 tsp (2.5 g) of salt and 0.25 tsp (1.25 g) of black pepper, then cook the roast as directed by your recipe. As a variation, sear the outside of the roast after adding the mustard paste but before applying the salt and pepper. Heat 2 US tbsp (30 mL) of vegetable oil in a large skillet over medium-high heat, then add the roast to the pan. Use tongs to turn the roast so that each side gets nicely browned. Remove the roast, let it cool for a couple minutes, then apply the salt and pepper and finish cooking it in the oven.
